segments.text: We're continuing on with college.
Okay.
Every time they would organize some kind of a protest, I would wear my uniform.
I got in with the small veterans club they had on campus, and they voted to allow me to go in to join the club, even though I was not out of the service, and I was an officer.
They had two strikes against me, but they allowed me to go ahead and join.
On one particular occasion the students were going to take down the flag in front of the administration building.
So we got ourselves organized and we made a roster of who had which classes at which times and we posted guards on the flag all day long and the flag didn't come down.
We had lots of debates in the student union and I'm not sure I convinced anybody of my way of thinking
I'm not sure they convinced me, but it was active in terms of participation on both sides.
I was the only active duty army person on the whole campus.
At the end of two years I knew about half of them and they all knew me.
Did you get into any real major blows, not physically, but verbal blows?
Oh, yes.
I was called, you know, a baby murderer to, you know, anything that was going along.
And you got a lot of that wash over and debate them at whatever level you felt best at.
The only time I ever really lost, I was invited to come into one of the
It was in the history department.
A guy by the name of Joe Carter, whom I had known for many years, was one of the professors.
Asked me if I would come in and be a guest speaker since Vietnam seemed to be a topic of greatest interest with all of the students.
And I could pretty well hold my own in a debate with any of the undergraduates.
But when I walked into this classroom, I found that not only do we have all of the undergraduates, we've got all of the graduate students and all of the faculty in this room.
Well, I did all right until I ended up taking on the head of the history department.
And I lost that one.
Regardless of what I said, the dean of the history department carried more weight than
Undergraduate, Lee Johnson.
You later went on to teach ROTC at Nevada University?
Mm-hmm.
After I finished up my degree at Adams State, I went to Benning for 10 months, finished a infantry officer's advance course.
and then got an assignment out to the University of Nevada, Reno as an ROTC instructor.
We had five guys there.
Reno was a unique campus.
It was liberal in its ideas to some degree and its proximity to California, and yet it was far enough away from Berkeley that we didn't have the violent protesting.
We had a fairly active ROTC department.
It was a land grant college, and every able-bodied male freshman was required to take one semester of ROTC.
We did not put these in uniform.
This was strictly academic.
Here's what the Army's all, or the military's all about.
We taught Army, Navy, Air Force,
Although there was no Army, I mean Navy or Air Force ROTC detachment, they were just Army, but because we were the only one there we taught cross service.
If they elected to come in and take ROTC after that, then we would put them in uniform and they had to make drills and all that, but for the freshmen we didn't do all that.
It was a trying and a rewarding experience.
The kids were the right age.
They had cut the relical cord from their parents, and yet they were still hungry for some kind of adult guidance.
They were moldable, enthusiastic, questioning, and bright, and they would suck as much of your time as you would absolutely give them.
many of the kids I graduated from there I later served with.
It was probably one of the best three years I ever spent in terms of being able to leave your stamp on the service.
You have anything you'd like to

expound on or in what regard just overall your whole period how has it affected your life how have you continued if you had to cope with it see I after my second tour I had nightmares for a little while over that one particular incident that we discussed earlier and finally one day I got out a bunch of maps and I went over the whole scenario and decided that
Given the information I had at the time, I would have done everything exactly the same.
And after that, I didn't have any problems dealing with it.
Understand that by this time I, well, by the time I finished up my second tour, I decided I was going to be a career officer.
I was very good at what I was doing.
I liked leading troops.
And I did it well.
I don't think any other single person could have done it with any less casualties than I did.
And I still had no qualms about being in Vietnam in terms of fighting at war other than the fact that I think we could have won if they had turned us loose.
Or if they decided it was not winnable, then we shouldn't have gotten in there.
And I can't blame that on the troops or the country.
While I was at UNR,
Vietnam fell.
And there was a graduate student there who was Vietnamese, whom everybody loved.
And when the country fell, he was cut off.
He had no place to go.
His family was still back in Vietnam and all that.
And everybody felt very sorry for him, except me.
And nobody could understand that.
And I said, look,
For eight years this kid has been in the United States going to college.
Well, I have spent more time in the last eight years in his country than he has.
If he was so worried about Vietnam, he should have been over there packing a rifle, not over here hiding and going to college.
I have no desire to ever go back and see Vietnam again.
And it was a beautiful country.
We messed it up a lot.
By the time we got through with that country, you could not go half a mile in any direction without seeing a very big hole in the ground left by a bomb somewhere.
Sure, eventually the bomb craters had fell down and they rebuilt part of the country,
At one time, Wayne was a beautiful city.
And by the time the NBA and us got through with it, it was mostly rubble.
But I remember seeing Europe when I was over there as a dependent in 1948.
And now you can't see any or very few scars of the war left in Europe.
I'd like to ask you a question.
What do you know about the Mealy incident?
I knew Rusty Cowley a little bit from the ranger department.

He and I were both in the ranger department at Fort Benning when most of the major investigations in the states were created and he was assigned over to building four at Fort Benning which is a big administration building where he spent
most of his time preparing his defense with his lawyer.

I was at Fort Bedding where the My Lai court-martial was taking place and was there all the time while he was basically under house arrest after the court-martial waiting for the appeal process to take place.
I'm convinced of a number of things.
Number one,
Rusty Calley was guilty of sin.
He was tried by a board of officers who had all been to Vietnam, who all understood the problems of command, who understood the problems of Vietnam, and they found him guilty.
The problem with Calley and the My Lai is more basic than an individual.
He was an OCS product.
He was 20 years old when the incident occurred.
He had not a degree nor very much military background.
He was in a unit that had been put together from a lot of different units into a division, so there was not the real history of a unit.
It had a lot of growing pains.
They were also in an area that was primarily a pacification program, so they didn't have

clear-cut enemy as much as they would go into what was supposedly a friendly village and they would take some horrendous losses when they finally get into the village there wouldn't be anybody there everybody would say oh they were friendly and you had men women and children the repetition of this over a long time caused a great deal of frustration and I think not only amongst the leaders
by amongst the troops.
I basically think that he just kind of went berserk one day.
What he did was absolutely wrong.
In any military conflict, there's going to be civilians that get hurt.
My standing orders to my troops used to be whenever we had to deal with a civilian populace, which was not very often,
If you see somebody running after you've told them to stand still, and we had Vietnamese interpreters and loudspeakers to do that, you shoot.
The troops, when they go into a village, don't have time to ask questions.
They don't have time to look real hard to see whether it's a guy's got a weapon or it's a 17-year-old kid or it's a 13-year-old kid.
You can't tell the difference when they're moving.
And it's very much like a policeman.
He walks outside of a bank, and he knows the bank's being robbed, and he sees somebody run out the door real quick, and he yells to him to halt, and he doesn't halt.
The policeman will probably shoot.
But if the guy stops, and he lines him up against the wall, and then shoots him, that's murder.
Basically, that's what Kelly did.
He said after they had captured these people, they shot them.
And a bunch of them.
The primary reason for having officers is to ensure that units operate within the realm of law.
Small units like platoons can operate probably as well under an NCO as they can under a platoon leader or a platoon commander.
But that is the training ground for higher ranking officers.
and is to ensure that units operate within the scope of the law.
Cali had neither the training nor the maturity nor the experience to carry that through.
You feel that reflected on the Army Officer Corps?
Most definitely.
Cali was probably not the only one
Our officer corps expanded tremendously in a period of a few years.
I was responsible for producing some of those lieutenants.
I ran an OCS company on a number of occasions.
I tried to bounce out people whom I thought would not be good officers.
And as an OCS company commander, I submitted reports to an evaluation board
that generally consisted of a lieutenant colonel, two majors, and a couple of captains.
They had to make an evaluation based on my reports and their interview with the prospective lieutenant of whether or not he would or would not remain in the program.
Many times, my evaluation and recommendation was overruled.
And one day I finally got mad and walked into the board and talked to the president of the board about, I would not have this character as one of my platoon leaders.
And he said, I understand what you're saying, Captain Johnson, but in many cases a lieutenant is better than no lieutenant.
And I said, yeah, but I would rather have a sergeant running it.
He said, yeah, but we don't have sergeants either.
I talked to you earlier about the NCO academy.

that our army had expanded so fast in such a short period of time that we had neither good qualified officers or ncos that understood and it doesn't come from reading a book but from the deep tradition bound understanding that comes with being a part of a unit and watching and observing
superiors that kind of understanding comes from.
I remember digging out all those letters.
He wrote me every day.
Were you ever accused or had any experience with other war atrocities that took place?
I, well I was in the advanced course, one of the young E-5s that had been in my company during my tenure.
And understand that when I took over my company, in the six month period before me, they had five company commanders.
All of them had been shot out from under the company.
The company that I was in was involved in a way during the test.
and they had two company commanders in less than three weeks.
One of these characters got out and joined the Vietnam Veterans Against the War and had made a number of allegations about the company commanders that he had served under.
I got called out of the advance course and reported out of the Provo Marshal's office to be interviewed, and the list of allegations ran from murder to petty theft.
After submitting my affidavit and answering all the questions on tape, charges were later dropped.
It wasn't really a charge at this point in time.
They were doing what they call an Article 32 investigation.
There's a civilian name for it.
I can't remember what it is, but basically it is a preliminary investigation to determine whether or not there is a basis for initiating court martial proceedings.
The investigation later resulted in them dropping all the charges because they found out that this kid was basically just trying to raise dust.
But it was enough to strike terror in my heart because at that point in time, in 1970, merely being accused was enough to ruin one's career.
How did you control your troops when they do get angry from having their buddies blown away?
How do you control them from
committing such atrocity?
By example and by letting them know absolutely that nothing will happen.
On one occasion, I think I mentioned to you when the tape was off, we had, we were moving through an area where we had killed a lot of people.
We had used artillery as well as mortars and
I came across, I usually ran my company command group right behind the first platoon and then I would have two platoons either out on the flank or behind me and the mortar platoon behind me.

And somebody had taken a bamboo stake or just a piece of bamboo and had chopped it off with a machete and taken a head of an NVA soldier that had been severed with what looked like artillery but some kind of a fragment and had
shoved it down on top of this bamboo stake and put a first calf patch in the mouth.

Well the NVA were predominantly Buddhist and the Buddhists were very superstitious or what we consider to be superstition in that if their body wasn't whole or at least together I mean all the parts of it in the burial place that they couldn't go to heaven and that used to really
caused serious morale problems with the NVA.
And it became common for many troops to leave either human patches or an ace of spades or something on the bodies as a calling card for the guys that came in and picked up the bodies later.
And it was a psychological game.
I simply got my lieutenants to put out the word.
I didn't want to know who did that, but I didn't want to ever see it again, and it never happened.
As long as the river is in command, we'll put out the word that what is acceptable as norms, the troops will fall in line with that.
And occasionally if somebody gets out a little bit, you bring it back into the fold.
Okay.
Do you have anything else you want to add on this topic?
I think every every time
This has been an interview with retired Army Lieutenant Colonel Lee Leonard C. Johnson.
His awards consist of one Silver Star, seven Bronze Stars, Air Medal, two Purple Hearts.
He served the Army from March 1963 to April 1984.
He served two tours in Vietnam from July 1966 to July 1967 and August of 1968 to August 1969.
He presently resides in Temple, Texas with his wife and two children.
